conclusion: Parallel-plate capacitor with capacitance C, charge on the capacitor plates is Q, distance between plates is d, point charge q is at the midpoint between plates.

premise: For a parallel-plate capacitor, the electric field between the plates is uniform and given by E = sigma / epsilon_0, where sigma is the surface charge density on the plates.
conclusion: The surface charge density sigma = Q / A, where A is the area of each plate.

premise: Capacitance C = epsilon_0 A / d, so A = Cd / epsilon_0.
conclusion: Therefore, sigma = Q / A = Q epsilon_0 / Cd.

premise: Substituting into the electric field equation E = sigma / epsilon_0.
conclusion: E = Q epsilon_0 / Cd epsilon_0 = Q / Cd.

premise: The electrostatic force on a charge in an electric field is F = qE.
conclusion: Substituting our electric field, F = q * Q / Cd.
The left plate has positive charge and the right plate has negative charge.

premise: If q is positive, it will be repelled by the positive plate and attracted to the negative plate.
conclusion: The force points toward the right (negative plate).

premise: If q is negative, it will be attracted to the positive plate and repelled by the negative plate.
conclusion: The force points toward the left (positive plate).

premise: The magnitude of the electrostatic force on the point charge q is F = qQ / Cd.
conclusion: The magnitude of the electrostatic force experienced by the point charge q at the midpoint between the plates is F = qQ / Cd.
